intro: Calea berteroana, commonly known as the "Mexican nightshade," is a flowering plant native to Mexico and Central America. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that open at night. The plant has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, edible berries that are sometimes used in traditional medicine. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Its unique nocturnal blooming habit makes it a fascinating subject for botanical study.
